report_title: The Declining Dollar Will Be a Boon for Operators
executive_summary: The US dollar is anticipated to fall during the outlook period, as investors are anticipated to purchase currencies from other countries, such as the Chinese Yuan. As the dollar depreciates, domestically produced goods become more attractive to foreign buyers, boosting exports. Since exports comprise a significant revenue share, the declining dollar will benefit fishermen.

industry_definition: Operators in the Fishing industry primarily catch finfish, shellfish and miscellaneous marine products for commercial sale with little to no alteration or further processing. Aquaculture is excluded, and companies that extract the bulk of their revenue through fish processing are also excluded.
key_trends: Revenue stalled significantly because of COVID-19
High seafood prices have boosted the industry's performance
Rising fuel costs represent a threat to operators
Rising incomes will increase demand for fish
Fish will become increasingly more attractive compared with meat

market_segmentation.segment_description: Food processors purchase fresh and frozen seafood so they can transform them into edible products (e.g., fillets, tails).
Involves buying of inedible products such as animal feed, pearls.
Wholesalers act as middlemen, purchasing fish products from operators.

products_and_services.product_description: Shellfish comprises a significant portion of revenue including crabs, lobsters, clams, and shrimp.
Finfish make up the largest share of revenue including species like Alaska Pollock, Tuna and Salmon.
Fish in the miscellaneous category include eel and octopus.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Influences demand due to exports forming part of the industry's revenue.
Higher prices for fish often decrease demand.
Frequency of eating away from home is closely related to income.
Shift from red meat to fish as a protein source due to increasing health concerns.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE UNITED STATES-MEXICO-CANADA AGREEMENT (USMCA) STRENGTHENS TIES WITH CANADA
international_trade_points.trade_description: Fosters trade between the United States and its North American neighbors.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE RECOVERY FROM COVID-19 HAS BOOSTED IMPORTS
international_trade_points.trade_description: When the economy opened in 2021, consumer spending surged.

international_trade_points.trade_title: NICHE MARKETS FOR ASIAN FISH HAVE EMERGED
international_trade_points.trade_description: Wealthier consumers exhibit interest in Asian seafood.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE PANDEMIC CAUSED INTERNATIONAL TRADE TO CRATER
international_trade_points.trade_description: As quarantine hit, spending plummeted impacting exports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: RECENT TRADE TENSIONS WITH CHINA HAVE HURT DOMESTIC FISHERMEN
international_trade_points.trade_description: Trade war initiated reduced exports to China.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE APPRECIATING DOLLAR CAUSES EXPORTS TO PLUNGE
international_trade_points.trade_description: Effects of a stronger dollar reducing foreign demand.

business_locations.location_description: The West region comprises states such as Alaska, California.
States in New England are located near cool waters.
The Southeast region is large with diverse bodies of water.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Every state requires operators to get a license.
Set limits on how many fish can be caught.
Set maximum catches for specific vessels.
Regulates fishing gear like hooks and nets.

barriers_points.barrier_description: States require fishing licenses with low qualifications.
Start-up costs for boats and materials are high.
Competition is on price and quality not branding.
Capital costs for boats/equipment are high.

basis_points.basis_description: Gaining access to commercial fishing waters.
Price is crucial, higher input costs lead to higher prices.
Larger producers are better positioned to compete.
Competes with alternative proteins like meat.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Initial costs of entry prevent large-scale domination.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fishing boats require lots of fuel.
Fishermen often rent dock and warehouse space.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: High capital costs relative to labor costs
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Purchasing trawlers incurs high capital costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Innovation is limited due to low new patent rates.
Difficult for new operators to enter and succeed.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Shifting exchange rates cause drastic changes.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advancements in power sources like biodiesel.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for fish is price-sensitive, and consumers will not hesitate to switch to imports at lower price points.

FAQs.question: Does your company participate in one product segment or an array of products?
FAQs.answer: Diversified fishers will exhibit lower revenue volatility; undiversified operators may have a specific reputation.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Fishers near key markets will have lower transportation costs and broader margins.

FAQs.question: Has your company been subject to excess revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Price-sensitive competition impacts stability; long-term contracts provide more stability.

FAQs.question: How has your company been leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Technologies like fish finders enhance operational efficiencies and profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs with technology?
FAQs.answer: Reduction in wage costs leads to higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety standards are met?
FAQs.answer: Compliance leads to lower insurance costs, aiding profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Compliance with catch limits is essential to avoid civil fines.

FAQs.question: What is the training process for new hires like?
FAQs.answer: A capable crew is essential; operators must pay above-average sector wages.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the TWI?
FAQs.answer: A decreasing trade-weighted index means the US dollar is falling, making exports less attractive.
